1828.05.text:
progression, which, as I showed you at the
beginning, is the most important.

1831.56.text: And this is how it was done.

1833.09.text:
We collected a group of patients, the numbers
are now much higher, which were diagnosed

1839.52.text:
with severe dysplasia, and before, they had
a low-grade dysplasia.

1845.33.text:
Then we had another group of women which had
the same low-grade dysplasia but returned

1851.20.text:
We had another group of women which were diagnosed
despite being involved in an active surveillance

1857.11.text:
program with severe dysplasia or even carcinoma,
but the pap smear before was normal, so that

1866.40.text:
So, we then hypothesized that those -- we
know already these are positive, these are

1871.70.text:
all negative, these are positive, but we hypothesized
that those low-grade lesions that show progression

1878.54.text:
are positive for 3Q and those that show regression
are negative for 3Q.

1883.85.text:
And this worked, essentially, with the sensitivity
of 100 percent and the specificity of 95 percent.

1896.42.text:
It's a particular feature of HPV, but you
can see that the point of no return in the

1903.51.text:
progression risk for individual lesion is
the acquisition of the specific cytogenetic

1908.83.text: abnormality that then defines the cancer entity.

1913.71.text:
We also were -- expected but were a little
bit shocked that, in some cases, where the

1924.94.text:

after a relatively short latency, the woman

1931.96.text:
was diagnosed with a carcinoma, we could detect
extra copies in a third of the cases in the

1939.70.text:
cases that were cytologically assessed as
being normal, and I just show you some examples

1946.53.text: Here there is a CIN1 lesion which has regressed.

1952.10.text:
So, there would not have been any other treatment
required.

1957.06.text:
Here we have a CIN2 lesions, and you can see

1964.38.text: two cells, and they have both three copies.

1968.04.text:
This lesion is progressed to high grade dysplasia
and carcinoma.

1973.83.text:
And this is the case that I mentioned to you
before which was assessed as being normal,

1979.85.text:
but you can see we have four copies of chromosome
3Q in the set of cells, and, again, they are

1987.27.text:
next to each, indicating that the acquisition
of aberration is the basis for cloning expansion.

1995.73.text:
I shall also emphasize that -- so, I talked
to a cytologist as Hopkins, and they come

2008.71.text: in the training program twice a year.

2014.21.text:
And every time at the beginning the one diagnosis
go up and then they learn a little and it

2019.95.text:
goes down, because it is obviously relatively
difficult to unambiguously assess the morphology.

2029.47.text:
And when I go to cytology meetings, there
are whole days that are -- where they discuss

2036.19.text:
on how to best repeat the reading of a pap
smear to avoid false negatives.

2041.46.text:
And the fact that it is relatively often repeated
is an acknowledgement of the fact that an

2049.09.text: individual pap smear is relatively ambiguous.

2052.90.text: But you cannot argue that there are 4 copies.

2058.25.text:
So, it's a binary -- I mean, you can ask your
6-year-old to -- probably younger -- to count

2068.34.text:
to four and make the statement, "This is not
two."

2071.27.text:
Therefore, they cannot even say -- make the
statement as cervical carcinoma, they can

2075.96.text:
even say, "There is a woman which -- whose
low-grade dysplastic lesion will eventually

2084.99.text:
So, it took us a long time to convince gynecologists
and pathologists to embrace that because,

2092.99.text:
I mean, the procedure for the collection of
this material would not even have to be changed

2097.79.text:
because there is now -- in particular, with

2102.97.text:
But, now finally Crest Diagnostic has embraced

2110.23.text: So, now I want to switch gears a little bit.

2114.01.text: I don't know what the time is.

2119.34.text:
And just talk a little bit how we not only
use genomic aberrations, but aberrations of

2125.44.text:
the transcriptome and injected genomic information
into a problem of treatment response in patients

2140.21.text:
And you know it better than I do, there are
many treatment options in solid tumors.

2144.71.text:
It can be surgery alone, surgery plus adjuvant
chemo, radiation or chemotherapy in colon

2154.93.text:
carcinomas, or neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed
by surgery, or other approaches, or, in some

2163.20.text:
instances, depending on the mobility of the
patient, maybe chemoradiation alone.

2170.42.text:
And the problem in rectal cancer is a real
clinical problem, because, based on a large

2176.22.text:
study which was conducted from the terminal
rectal cancer group and has been adopted now

2184.73.text:
in most of Europe, I know it's not quite completely
adopted in the United States, the standard

2190.82.text:
treatment of locally advanced rectal cancer
is neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, mostly based

2199.04.text:
on 5-FU radiation, followed by surgery and
chemotherapy.

2205.28.text:
And the reason for that is that they found
out that if pre-surgery chemoradiotherapy

2212.95.text:
is administered, there is a higher rate of
R0 resection reception, there was a higher

2218.71.text:
rate of sphincter preserving receptions, and
there was a reduction of local occurrences,

2225.85.text: significant from, I believe, 14 to 6 percent.

2231.36.text:
The profound clinical problem is that the
response to neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy

2241.72.text:
You can have complete pathological response
in that case, where, after surgery, there

2247.43.text: is not a single tumor cell left.

2249.63.text:
Or, you have essentially complete resistance
where the tumor just doesn't bother being

2258.68.text:
So, we generated, together with a former post
doc of mine, Michael Ghadimi, who is now the

2265.43.text:
Chair of Surgery at the University in Göttingen,
Germany, a clinical research unit -- you can

2270.98.text:
look it up -- in order to address that problem,
and we aimed at identifying predictors of

2278.35.text:
response and identify targets of that and
understand mechanisms that could explain this

2292.80.text:
And in order to do so, we initially designed
this pilot study with 30 patients.

2299.99.text:
They all had pre-treatment clinical staging
based on rectal ultrasound.

2306.83.text:
We then collected tumor biopsies and performed
gene expression profiling.

2314.17.text: Obviously can barely see from here.

2318.47.text:
But then they went to this neoadjuvant scheme,
which is chemotherapy followed by surgery

2327.47.text:
and four rounds of 5-FU, and then we had the
long-term follow-up.

2332.06.text:
And pathological staging is shown here, and,
as I said, we performed gene expression profiling,

2339.08.text:
and then evaluated the local and distant reoccurrences
after median follow-up times of 44 months.

2344.93.text:
And the gene expression profiling worked actually
fairly well.

2348.58.text:
Here we had -- I forgot how many -- over 30
cases.

2355.56.text:
Approximately half of them had non-responding
tumors.

2361.31.text:
Fewer had tumors that showed a complete response,
and a gene expression profiling could actually

2367.69.text: fairly well discern these two groups.

2373.05.text:
But then we looked at the genes that were
unregulated in the tumors that were resistant.

2379.62.text:
And among those were the transcription factor
TCF4, and this obviously rings a bell the

2388.41.text:
transcription factor of TCF4 is the major
effector of WNT signaling in colorectal tumor

2396.06.text:
-- of the major effect of WNT signaling, of
course, not only in colorectal tumors.

2401.56.text:
And WNT signaling is intricately involved
in colorectal tumor -- effect on mutations

2407.92.text:
in the adanomatous polyposis instability and
resulted in stability of catenin, which then

2415.39.text:
actually increases the expression of the transcription
factor of TCF4, which in turn turns on cyclin,

2423.07.text:
D1, c-MYC, and other notorious oncogenes,
and therefore transforms the cells.

2429.26.text: So, that was a very interesting lead.

2433.95.text:
So, we hypothesized that silencing of a gene
that is overexpressed in resistant tumors

2446.35.text:
And we did the silencing with the approach
of using RNA interference, and I don't go

2453.02.text:
into details here, but if you inject small
interfering RNAs into cells, you can reduce

2460.17.text:
either protein synthesis or you can leave
the transcript which results in a loss of

2466.83.text:
function, and you can do that essentially
for any gene of interest.

2470.79.text:
So, we used small interfering RNA against
the transcription factor TCF4, and asked the

2478.05.text:
question if the silencing of TCF4 would increase
sensitivity of colorectal cancer cells to

2486.43.text: Here you can see the results.

2487.45.text:
It was a very effective silencing, here shown
in the reduction of protein.

2492.18.text:
We repeated that with many different constructs,
and when the results were then subjected to

2502.12.text:
radiation and not shown here, but also to
chemoradiation -- this is a log scale -- you

2507.96.text:
can see here the control, and you can see
here a profound sensitization after silencing

2516.35.text:
of the transcription factor TCF4, which, in
primary tumor samples, was overexpressed in

2522.24.text: those that were resistant to treatment.

2526.23.text:
Conclusion: Reduced expression of TCF4 leads
to a sensitization to radiation.

2531.14.text:
We are now exploring whether we can recapitulate
using small molecule inhibitors of WNT signaling,

2540.20.text:
and together with this clinical research in
Göttingen, we are about to design clinical

2550.49.text:
So, in summary, we have performed gene expression
profiling, which I have shown you, in rectal

2560.76.text:
carcinomas that are resistant or sensitive
to neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy.

2568.03.text:
We have also queried many different level
of the genome using CGH to see whether we

2575.03.text:
have specific genomic imbalances that may
explain the sensitivity.

2579.02.text: We have performed microRNA expression profiling.

2582.80.text:
We explored KRAS and BRAF mutation, which,
by the way, did not explain different sensitivity

2590.08.text:
We looked at the methylation status in collaboration
with Stephen Chanock.

2596.97.text:
We used 1 million Illumina platform to look
for single nucleotide polymorphisms in the

2604.90.text:
group of patients that respond differentially
to see -- to explore whether certain haplotypes,

2612.27.text:
for instance, in genes that involved in direct
metabolism, could explain the profound clinical

2622.73.text:
We do all this in order to address the problem
that all drives us, which is that patients

2632.33.text:
coming to the clinic with different clinical
features they have a different genetic makeup

2638.44.text:
and a different tumor biology, and, in the
case of rectal carcinomas, they also have

2647.38.text:
And this is not only true for rectal carcinomas
but a different genetic makeup of, for instance,

2653.05.text:
pre-malignant lesions in the cervix could
be summarized here.

2657.76.text:
However, despite these acknowledged differences
which we do not understand to the extent we

2666.08.text:
should, all these patients receive identical

2669.89.text:
The goal of all of us, of course, is to learn

2675.07.text:
-- I have not listed next-generation sequencing
here, which is important as well -- to learn

2680.72.text:
enough about the genetic makeup so that we
can assign patients to therapies from which

With that, I am at the end, and I thank you
